review_title: Good School, drastic misuse of funds
pros: Fantastic quality of education, many good profs, good community, I don't regret my 5 years here.
cons:
Some profs are impossible to understand or are illiterate in their subjects; RateMyProfessor is your best friend. Administration wastes our money on random things or a blatant misuse of funds; the president has 3 or 4 Tesla's and had a multi-million dollar kitchen renovation, meanwhile Residential Life is forced to give out post-it note packs and generic pens to try to get participation to their events because their budget is so small.

Overall, this is a great school, but don't assume anyone is going to help you.

pros: Everyone here is incredibly smart and competent, from administrative staff to high-rank faculty. I have never worked with more helpful and reliable people. QU also has a great atmosphere around work/life balance. On the tenure track, I do not feel the same stresses and pressures reported at other mid-sized private colleges.
cons: QU does not really give raises, except for when you go up for promotion. I’ve been here three years and there has not even been a COL adjustment to my salary. There is no union, so they are not held accountable.

pros: Health benefits and vacation time is really good.
cons: Not much room to move up and salary is not great compared to corporate work.

pros: Benefits, culture, work-life balance, campus. I have a great supervisor.
cons: Lack of room for growth in some areas. Disconnect from president’s office to professional schools. Limited diversity, but are actively working on it.

pros: Great staff - helped me learn so much on the job. Flexible with scheduling around classes. One of the best work-studies at QU.
cons: I don't have any cons.

pros: Great leadership, comfortable work environment, flexibility
cons: None, I love working here

pros: The university makes an effort to focus on quality education.
cons: The top leadership and many recently implemented policies promote a leftist agenda. Efforts to indoctrinate increasingly interfere with the core mission of the university to educate.

pros: Training, Resources, Supportive Surrounding Community

review_title: Great benefits, long hours with little reward
pros: Great benefits (403B, vacation time, )
cons: Expected to do more with less often.

pros: Many nice people and dedicated faculty/ academic leaders. Good benefits, retirement, medical, tuition, PTO.  If you don't ruffle feathers, you can have a cushy job with a lot of time off and great benefits for life. Pretty facade (campus) and no stinting on technology.
cons:
One of the most intolerant, reactionary, opaque workplaces I have ever encountered. President drives the fear-based culture but if you're on his good side, you can prosper. A"friends and family" club of long-term insiders, many of whom are promoted way beyond their capacity or merit, and  line their pockets handsomely at the expense of the little people (staff, hourly, adjuncts). Board is mesmerized by Lahey and doesn't look closely enough. Cult-like loyalty and fear abounds in the ranks. 
Many "institutes" sound good but look under the surface and you will find they are only one or two people. So much at QU is a mile wide and an inch deep.
Lip service only for diversity. 
Bait and switch on budget is frequent. Don't count on anything bring what it appears.

pros: I worked in the Admissions Office.  The best reason to work for QU admissions is that most of the counselors are down to earth and very easy to approach and talk to.  Everybody seems happy to be there.  They are very accomodating when it comes to work schedule and time off.  There is a strong sense of community within the office.  Everybody knows everybody.  Communication is a top priority in the office.
cons:
Good luck finding a place to sit.  The office is small.  Forget about an office, some of the counselors don't even have a space to sit at.  

Another downside is that the administration of the school is not very sensitive to social matters.  The president of the University seems to be more concerned about expanding facility space for the school instead of improving the academic progress of the school.  This is seen via lack of professors, lack of traditional departments (i.e. foreign language), and continued isolation from the surrounding community.  Diversity is lacking in the office as well as on the campus.  These qualities of the school make working in the admissions office difficult because they are glaring problems that require damage control from admissions staff.

review_title: Great People and place to work
pros: People are flexible and supportive
cons: too much values for students

pros:
Every professor (adjunct through full time) was incredibly nice and supportive. I taught an intro lab course for freshmen and an elective science class for sophmores - seniors. I was able to meet with the department head, two full time professors and the head of the teaching office for help in the elective course. The lab course was very well laid out and I could reach out to almost anyone for help and materials. 


The students were okay. Respectful. Engaged. Motivated. Somewhat spoiled- needed to be spoon fed with the worlds tiniest silver spoon. There was a large difference between the freshmen and the elective class, which indicates that the school is doing something right.
cons:
They promise the students that they will never interact with a teaching assistant, which means that they call everyone who teaches there "professor.", regardless of degree or what that degree was in. We had people with masters degrees in education teaching science courses.   


A lot of the adjuncts taught full classes including introductory courses. The students were also promised that every class will be less than 60 students, which means a lot of the introductory courses. Some adjuncts stayed for years, but there was also a ton of turnover. The freshmen often complained that their introductory course was off schedule/taught differently then the other introductory courses. My elective students were annoyed that such an inexperienced professor was teaching them.

pros: Decent job with paid training
cons: Boring job reading off a script

review_title: Great people, little opportunities for advancement for adjuncts
pros: Great faculty who care about their adjuncts
cons: Little opportunity for advancement for adjuncts

pros: great colleagues, opportunities for growth
cons: overworked department chairs and program directors

pros: Community, Student engagement, Flexible schedule
cons: No tenure opportunities in this department

pros: They treat their employees well
cons: They are not the best with pay

review_title: Great forever or until you find another Job
pros: Very Flexible schedule, nice people, good hours, OK pay, management is good at helping you have time off during emergencies or sick time. If you are a night time owl this job is perfect for you.
cons: Some times we have days or weeks off, can not go above 19.5 hours or 1,000hrs in a year, have to get use to people yelling at you on the phone (this job does teach patience however). There are not a lot of opportunities to go up in the Institute.

review_title: OLD PEOPLE+SMALL SPACES+FEW AMERICANS ANSWER THE PHONE
pros: Easy job. Polite respectful managers. Managers have no egos. you get paid around 1pm every fri like clockwork.
cons: Small cubicles. Small hallways. Small lunchroom->it's really a break room. Most common age group is late 40s-60s.A lot of disabled people work there. Maybe about 11 or 12. A lot of chubby people. Sometimes there are 160 people working at once. And only 20 people can fit into the lunch room at a time. So the breaks which are 10 minutes long are separated into waves. usually there are 110 people working. 160 people maybe working a couple times a month. total number of employees=about 350

job_title: Technical Support Associate in Hamden, CT
pros: Great coworkers, opportunities for advancement at all levels, personable managers. Pleasant place all around, and the beautiful scenery doesn't hurt either.
cons: Getting feedback on job performance from peers takes a long, long time. If someone has a problem with another person (except sexual harassment) it isn't dealt with right away, and ends up festering unless the person who was "wronged" pushes for it to be worked out. Otherwise, anonymous complaints take forever to get back to the offender.

review_title: Great university with some current challenges
pros: Quinnipiac University is a great place to work with an amazing collection of students, faculty, and staff. Just very welcoming and friendly people who are upbeat and energetic toward making it a special place.
cons: Recent drop in admitted students have led to short-sighted budget cuts that have not been well thought out. This has negatively impacted students, faculty, and the overall morale of the school.

job_title: GA Student Employment in Hamden, CT
pros: You learn a lot, you are able to get hands on experience and your supervisor, Regina, really makes sure you have support and opportunity for growth
cons: None really as you are given a great amount of responsibility but you always have someone to reach out to should you have questions

review_title: Once A Great Place To Work
pros:
Great benefits, pretty campus, some great co workers, some of the best technology, and easy parking. It is great to work with the students and keeping up with the latest trends of campus life.

Great experiences across other departments with people that really love what they do and enjoy  helping students.

Free tuition for you and immediate family members as long as you are employed. Free sports tickets.
cons:
No communication through the IT department at all whether for  normal projects or in emergencies. Many people want you to do their job for them because they can't be bothered. Others will not even answer their phone. Your director or manager will only care about money or how they look to their boss instead of your well being. Prices for food are ASTRONOMICAL. Company spends more money on the look of the school than paying their behind the scenes workers well. BE AWARE they will hire you for your qualifications but the second things go wrong you will be blamed.

Systems are BROKEN because they are not a "priority" to management. You would think they would be number 1 at such a technology forward company. 

Greatly underpaid for the amount of time worked or even starting in the field your starting at. If your planning on living on your own with just this job as an income it will be VERY tough.  For a school that charges close to 40K to attend a semester your salary doesn't see it. 

NOTE: Before major changes after they fired a good number of the teaching staff things started to go down hill. Culture has changed to fear, people are confused as to what is going on, directors are looking at their bottom line and not doing their best to safeguard their employees.

pros: They give direction and there is not too much oversight depending where you work.
cons: However, some of the work areas are a little dirty. Furthermore, they do not seem to have very many motivational factors in place for better performance.

review_title: Not the place it used to be....
pros: Beautiful campus, great people to work with, up and coming school.
cons: The environment has changed a great deal in the last few years; from a supportive environment to corporate. If you're part of a union on campus there is very little opportunity to move up.
